These bacteria's ability to adjust gene expression in response to available nutrients in the environment is directly associated with their pathogenic behavior [ 6 7 6 8 Carbohydrates as carbon sources have demonstrated specific impacts on the regulation of virulence factors, influencing the expression of components crucial for adhesion and tissue invasion [ 7 6 8 Klebsiella K. variicola 2. Growth Curve The growth curve was carried out to determine the multiplication capacity of each strain using different carbon sources. Discussion Bacterial survival depends on the successful colonization of diverse and dynamic environments, both inside and outside the host, requiring metabolic adaptation to available carbon sources [ 14 K. variicola Our results showed that all strains used in an efficient way glucose, sorbitol, fructose, sucrose, and galactose as carbon sources by providing high growth rates and low generation time, highlighting their metabolic flexibility ( Figure 1 14 15 Predominantly found in human body fluids and tissues and primarily involved in protein glycosylation rather than in carbohydrate metabolism, mannose incubation resulted in the slowest growth rate for all classical strains tested (cKv15, cKv35, and cKv57). These findings indicate reduced efficiency in supporting K. variicola 16 K. variicola Galactose, maltose, and sorbitol yielded the highest biomass in early and mature biofilm by the cKv isolates ( Table 1 Figure 2a 17 18 The HMV strain was isolated from a root canal in the oral cavity of a young woman and represents the first K. variicola 7 19 Figure 2a Siderophores are crucial for bacterial survival in host fluids.
